ground_truth: Butch peers around a wall, taking in the vital information, walks out of the alley, and is ready for anything. He crosses the street and enters his apartment courtyard in North Hollywood, where everything appears normal: the laundry room, the pool, and his apartment door are undisturbed. Butch climbs the stairs to his apartment, number 12, steps outside the door, listens inside, and slowly inserts the key, quietly opening it to find that his apartment hasn't been touched. He cautiously steps inside, shuts the door, takes a quick look around, walks into his modest kitchen, and opens the refrigerator before going to the bedroom. His bedroom, like the rest of the apartment, is neat, clean, and anonymous, and sure enough, the watch is as he said it was—on the bedside table, hanging on his little kangaroo statue. He walks through the apartment back into the kitchen, opens a cupboard, takes out a box of Pop Tarts, puts down the milk, opens the box, takes out two Pop Tarts, and puts them in the toaster. Butch glances to his right and sees a small compact Czech M61 submachine gun with a huge silencer on the kitchen counter, which makes him laugh out loud. As he laughs, he flips a tape in the cassette player, and when the music starts, he sings along with it. He drives by the apartment but is stopped at the light on the corner across from Teriyaki Donut, still chuckling and singing along with the song. Marsellus Wallace exits Teriyaki Donut, carrying a box of a dozen donuts and two large styrofoam cups of coffee, steps off the curb, and crosses the street in front of Butch's car. Laughing boy stops when he sees Marsellus in front of him; Marsellus casually glances at Butch, continues walking, and Butch stomps on the gas pedal. The Honda slams into Marsellus, sending him, the donuts, and the coffee hitting the pavement at thirty miles an hour. Butch cuts into cross traffic and is broad-sided by a gold Camaro Z-28, breaking all the windows in the Honda and sending it up on the sidewalk. Butch sits dazed and confused in the crumpled mess of what was Fabienne's Honda, with blood flowing from his nostrils, as a pedestrian pokes his head inside. Marsellus Wallace lies sprawled out in the street, gawkers gather around the body, and the yelling makes Marsellus come to.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Butch gazes around a partition, absorbing the essential details, strides out of the passageway, and is prepared for anything. He traverses the road and enters his residence courtyard in North Hollywood, where everything seems routine: the washroom, the pool, and his apartment entry remain intact. Butch ascends the steps to his residence, number 12, stands outside the entry, listens inside, and gradually inserts the key, softly unlocking it to find that his apartment hasn't been disturbed. He cautiously enters, closes the door, takes a swift glance around, walks into his simple kitchen, and opens the refrigerator before heading to the bedroom. His bedroom, like the rest of the apartment, is tidy, spotless, and impersonal, and sure enough, the timepiece is as he said it was—on the bedside stand, hanging on his little kangaroo figurine. He walks through the apartment back into the kitchen, opens a cabinet, takes out a box of Pop Tarts, sets down the milk, opens the box, extracts two Pop Tarts, and places them in the toaster. Butch glances to his right and perceives a diminutive compact Czech M61 submachine gun with a massive suppressor on the kitchen counter, which causes him to laugh out loud. As he laughs, he flips a tape in the cassette player, and when the music begins, he sings along with it. He drives by the apartment but is halted at the signal on the corner across from Teriyaki Donut, still chuckling and singing along with the tune. Marsellus Wallace exits Teriyaki Donut, carrying a container of a dozen donuts and two large styrofoam cups of coffee, steps off the curb, and traverses the street in front of Butch's vehicle. Laughing boy stops when he notices Marsellus in front of him; Marsellus casually glances at Butch, continues walking, and Butch stomps on the accelerator. The Honda crashes into Marsellus, sending him, the donuts, and the coffee hitting the pavement at thirty miles an hour. Butch cuts into cross traffic and is broad-sided by a gold Camaro Z-28, shattering all the windows in the Honda and sending it onto the sidewalk. Butch sits stunned and perplexed in the crumpled wreck of what was Fabienne's Honda, with blood flowing from his nostrils, as a bystander pokes his head inside. Marsellus Wallace lies sprawled out in the street, onlookers gather around the body, and the shouting makes Marsellus regain consciousness.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Butch peers around a wall, vital information is taken in by him, walks out of the alley, and is ready for anything. The street is crossed by him, and the apartment courtyard in North Hollywood is entered, where everything appears normal: the laundry room, the pool, and his apartment door remain undisturbed. The stairs to his apartment, number 12, are climbed by Butch; he steps outside the door, listens inside, and the key is slowly inserted by him, quietly opening it to find that nobody has touched his apartment. He cautiously steps inside, the door is shut by him, a quick look around is taken, he walks into his modest kitchen, the refrigerator is opened by him before he goes to the bedroom. His bedroom, like the rest of the apartment, he keeps neat, clean, and anonymous, and sure enough, he has the watch as he said it was—on the bedside table, hanging on his little kangaroo statue. Walking through the apartment back into the kitchen, he opens a cupboard, a box of Pop Tarts is taken out, he puts down the milk, the box is opened by him, two Pop Tarts are taken out, and they are put in the toaster by him. Butch glances to his right and a small compact Czech M61 submachine gun with a huge silencer is seen on the kitchen counter, which makes him laugh out loud. As he laughs, a tape is flipped by him in the cassette player, and when the music starts, he sings along with it. He drives by the apartment but stops at the light on the corner across from Teriyaki Donut, still chuckling and singing along with the song. Teriyaki Donut is exited by Marsellus Wallace, who carries a box of a dozen donuts and two large styrofoam cups of coffee, steps off the curb, and the street in front of Butch's car is crossed by him. Laughing boy stops when Marsellus is seen in front of him; Marsellus casually glances at Butch, continues walking, and the gas pedal is stomped on by Butch. Marsellus is slammed into by the Honda, sending him, the donuts, and the coffee hitting the pavement at thirty miles an hour. Cross traffic is cut into by Butch, and a gold Camaro Z-28 broad-sides him, breaking all the windows in the Honda and sending it up on the sidewalk. Butch sits dazed and confused in the crumpled mess of what was Fabienne's Honda, with blood flowing from his nostrils, as a pedestrian pokes his head inside. Marsellus Wallace lies sprawled out in the street, the body is gathered around by gawkers, and the yelling makes Marsellus come to.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Butch peers around a wall, absorbing crucial details, then leaves the alley, ready for anything. He crosses the street into his North Hollywood apartment courtyard, where everything seems normal: the laundry room, pool, and apartment door are undisturbed. Ascending to apartment 12, he listens, inserts the key, and finds his place untouched. Inside, he checks his neat, clean bedroom, confirming his watch is on the bedside table, hanging on a kangaroo statue. In the kitchen, he opens a cupboard, grabs a box of Pop Tarts, sets down the milk, and prepares two in the toaster. Butch spots a Czech M61 submachine gun with a silencer on the counter, laughing out loud. Flipping a tape, he sings along with the music. Driving by the apartment, he is stopped at a light across Teriyaki Donut, still chuckling and singing. Marsellus Wallace exits with donuts and coffee, crosses in front of Butch's car. Butch stomps on the gas, hitting Marsellus, sending him, the donuts, and coffee flying. Butch cuts into cross traffic, colliding with a gold Camaro Z-28, shattering the Honda's windows and landing on the sidewalk. Dazed, Butch sits in the wrecked Honda, blood from his nostrils, as a pedestrian peers in. Marsellus lies sprawled on the street as onlookers gather, and their yelling revives him.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Butch observes from a wall, leaves the alley, and reaches his apartment in North Hollywood, where all seems undisturbed. He enters apartment 12, checks it, and finds the watch on the bedside table. In the kitchen, he prepares Pop Tarts and notices a submachine gun, laughing as he flips a tape in the player and sings. Driving away, he stops at a light near Teriyaki Donut. Marsellus Wallace crosses with donuts and coffee; Butch accelerates, hitting him. Butch's car crashes into a Camaro, leaving him dazed and bleeding as onlookers gather around Marsellus, who regains consciousness.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Butch, cautious and vigilant, peers around the corner of a concealing wall, taking in all the vital information with keen eyes. With a newfound readiness for anything life might throw at him, he strides confidently out of the dim alleyway. As he crosses the bustling street, he makes his way toward the familiar, welcoming confines of his apartment courtyard in the vibrant area of North Hollywood. Here, everything appears perfectly ordinary and undisturbed: the laundry room stands still, the pool shimmers under the sunlight, and the threshold to his apartment remains untouched and silent. 

With a deliberate pace, Butch ascends the stairs that lead to his apartment, number 12. He pauses outside his door, pressing his ear softly against it to listen for any unusual sounds from within. Hearing nothing amiss, he slowly and quietly inserts the key into the lock, gently turning it and opening the door to find his apartment undisturbed and exactly as he left it. With cautious steps, he enters, shutting the door behind him. After a quick, reassuring glance around the surroundings, he proceeds into his modest kitchen, where he opens the refrigerator before heading toward the bedroom.

Once in his bedroom, he observes that it, like the rest of his humble apartment, remains neat and clean in an almost anonymous manner. True to his earlier assurance, the watch is precisely where he said it would be—resting on the bedside table, draped over his little kangaroo statue. After retrieving the watch, Butch moves back through the apartment and into the kitchen once more. He opens a cupboard and takes out a box of Pop Tarts, setting the milk down before opening the box and placing two Pop Tarts into the toaster.

As he stands in his kitchen, Butch's gaze shifts to his right, where he notices a small, compact Czech M61 submachine gun lying on the counter, equipped with a massive silencer. This unexpected sight triggers a hearty laugh. Amid his laughter, he flips a tape in the cassette player, and as the music begins to play, he can't help but sing along. Later, as he drives his car past the apartment, he finds himself stopped at a red light right at the corner across from Teriyaki Donut, still chuckling and harmonizing with the song.

Meanwhile, Marsellus Wallace emerges from Teriyaki Donut, carrying a box filled with a dozen freshly baked donuts and two large styrofoam cups brimming with coffee. He steps off the curb and saunters across the street in front of Butch's car. As Butch, still amused, comes to a stop upon spotting Marsellus directly in front of him, Marsellus offers a casual, fleeting glance toward Butch before continuing on his path. Butch makes a sudden decision; he forcefully stomps on the gas pedal. The Honda surges forward, colliding with Marsellus, sending him, along with the donuts and coffee, sprawling across the pavement at thirty miles an hour.

In a desperate maneuver, Butch swerves into cross traffic, only to be violently broad-sided by a gleaming gold Camaro Z-28. The impact shatters all the windows of the Honda, sending the vehicle careening onto the sidewalk. Butch finds himself sitting dazed and utterly confused amidst the wreckage of what was once Fabienne's beloved Honda, blood flowing freely from his nostrils. A concerned pedestrian approaches and peers inside, assessing the damage. Meanwhile, Marsellus Wallace lies spread out on the street, surrounded by curious onlookers who gather around his prone body. The commotion reaches his ears, and amidst the yelling, Marsellus slowly begins to regain consciousness.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Butch, with a demeanor that can best be described as cautious and vigilant, carefully peers around the corner of a concealing wall. His sharp eyes take in all the vital information, absorbing every detail of the surroundings. Feeling an enhanced readiness for whatever unexpected challenges life might present, he strides confidently out of the dim confines of the alleyway. As he crosses the bustling street, he makes deliberate progress toward the familiar and welcoming confines of his apartment courtyard, nestled in the vibrant and lively area of North Hollywood. Here, everything appears perfectly ordinary and undisturbed, creating a deceptive calm: the laundry room stands motionless, the pool shimmers gently under the bright sunlight, and the threshold to his apartment remains untouched and silent, unchanged since he last saw it.

With a deliberate and measured pace, Butch ascends the stairs leading to his apartment, number 12. He pauses momentarily outside his door, pressing his ear softly against it to listen intently for any unusual or suspicious sounds from within. Hearing nothing at all amiss, he slowly and quietly inserts the key into the lock, gently turning it and opening the door to find that his apartment remains undisturbed and precisely as he left it before. With cautious steps, he enters, shutting the door quietly behind him. After a reassuring glance around his surroundings, he proceeds into his modest kitchen. There, he opens the refrigerator briefly before heading toward his bedroom.

Upon entering his bedroom, he observes that it, like the rest of his humble apartment, remains neat and clean in an almost anonymous manner. True to his earlier assurance, the watch is precisely where he said it would be—resting on the bedside table, draped over his little kangaroo statue. After retrieving the watch to his satisfaction, Butch moves back through the apartment and into the kitchen once more. He opens a cupboard and takes out a box of Pop Tarts, setting the milk down before opening the box and placing two Pop Tarts into the toaster.

As he stands in his small kitchen, Butch's gaze shifts to his right, where he notices a small, compact Czech M61 submachine gun lying conspicuously on the counter, equipped with a massive silencer. This unexpected sight is so jarring that it triggers a hearty laugh from him. Amid his laughter, he flips a tape in the cassette player, and as the music begins to play, he finds himself unable to resist singing along with the tune. Later, as he drives his car past the apartment building, he finds himself stopped at a red light right at the corner across from Teriyaki Donut, still chuckling and harmonizing with the song.

Meanwhile, Marsellus Wallace emerges from Teriyaki Donut, carrying a box brimming with a dozen freshly baked donuts and two large styrofoam cups filled to the brim with steaming coffee. He steps off the curb with his characteristic saunter and crosses the street directly in front of Butch's car. As Butch, still amused, comes to a stop upon spotting Marsellus directly in front of him, Marsellus offers a casual, fleeting glance towards Butch before continuing on his path across the street. Butch, in a moment of sudden impulsivity, makes a decisive decision; he forcefully stomps on the gas pedal. The Honda surges forward, colliding with Marsellus and sending him, along with the donuts and coffee, sprawling across the pavement at a velocity of thirty miles an hour.

In a desperate maneuver to regain control, Butch swerves into the unpredictable chaos of cross-traffic, only to be violently broad-sided by a gleaming gold Camaro Z-28. The impact is so severe that it shatters all the windows of the Honda, sending the vehicle careening uncontrollably onto the nearby sidewalk. Butch finds himself sitting dazed and utterly confused amidst the wreckage of what was once Fabienne's beloved Honda, blood flowing freely from his nostrils. A concerned pedestrian approaches cautiously and peers inside, assessing the damage with growing concern. Meanwhile, Marsellus Wallace lies sprawled on the street, surrounded by curious and concerned onlookers who gather around his prone body. The commotion reaches his ears, and amidst the chaotic yelling, Marsellus slowly begins to regain consciousness, gradually becoming aware of his dire situation.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Butch cautiously peeks around the wall, his eyes scanning the surroundings to gather any crucial details that might affect his next move. With the vital information collected, he confidently walks out of the alley, mentally preparing himself for any situation he might encounter. He decisively crosses the street, his eyes focused ahead, and enters the courtyard of his apartment in North Hollywood, noting with relief that the familiar sights—the laundry room, the pool, and his apartment door—all remain undisturbed. He climbs the stairs leading to his apartment, number 12, and pauses outside the door, listening intently for any sounds inside before slowly inserting the key into the lock. He quietly opens the door, his eyes scanning the interior, confirming that nothing inside has been tampered with. With a cautious step, he enters the apartment, gently shutting the door behind him before casting a quick, observant glance around the living room. Satisfied, he walks into his modest kitchen and pulls open the refrigerator door, surveying the contents for a brief moment before heading to the bedroom. The bedroom, like the rest of the apartment, remains neat, clean, and impersonal, and as he had hoped, his watch is exactly where he left it—resting on the bedside table, draped over a small kangaroo statue. After a moment of reassurance, he walks back through the apartment into the kitchen, opening a cupboard to retrieve a box of Pop Tarts. He sets down the milk, opens the box, takes out two Pop Tarts, and places them in the toaster, anticipating a snack. As he does so, his eyes shift to the right, landing on a small compact Czech M61 submachine gun with an oversized silencer sitting conspicuously on the kitchen counter, eliciting a genuine laugh from him. Amused, he flips a tape in the cassette player, and as the music starts to play, he begins to sing along, the melody lifting his spirits. Later, while driving past the apartment, he halts at a red light at the corner across from Teriyaki Donut, still chuckling and singing to the tune playing in his car. Meanwhile, Marsellus Wallace exits Teriyaki Donut, his hands full with a box of a dozen donuts and two large styrofoam cups of coffee, before stepping off the curb and beginning to cross the street directly in front of Butch's car. The lightheartedness vanishes as Butch halts his singing upon seeing Marsellus in front of him; Marsellus makes brief eye contact with Butch, nonchalantly continuing his walk across the street. In a swift and deliberate motion, Butch floors the gas pedal, the Honda surging forward to collide with Marsellus, propelling him, the donuts, and the coffee onto the pavement at thirty miles an hour. As chaos ensues, Butch swerves into cross traffic, only to be violently broad-sided by a gold Camaro Z-28, the impact shattering all the windows in Fabienne's Honda and launching it onto the sidewalk. Amidst the wreckage, Butch sits stunned and disoriented in the demolished remains of the car, blood dripping steadily from his nostrils as a concerned pedestrian leans in to check on him. Meanwhile, Marsellus Wallace lies sprawling in the street, passersby gathering around his fallen form. The raucous commotion from the onlookers eventually rouses Marsellus back to consciousness.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Butch emerges from the alley, alert and prepared, crosses the street, and enters his apartment courtyard in North Hollywood, noting the undisturbed surroundings. After cautiously entering his apartment, he confirms everything is intact, including his watch on the bedside table. He heads to the kitchen, takes out Pop Tarts, and starts toasting them when he notices a small Czech M61 submachine gun with a silencer on the counter, which amuses him. Laughing, he flips a tape in the cassette player and sings along. Later, while driving by his apartment, he stops at a light across from Teriyaki Donut. Marsellus Wallace exits the shop and crosses in front of Butch's car. Recognizing Marsellus, Butch accelerates, hitting him and sending Marsellus, along with donuts and coffee, tumbling onto the pavement. Butch then collides with a Camaro Z-28, leaving him dazed in the wrecked Honda as a pedestrian checks on him. Meanwhile, Marsellus, sprawled on the street, begins to regain consciousness amid a gathering crowd.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Butch, once a former prizefighter who now lives a quieter life, peers around a wall, taking in the vital information, walks out of the alley, and is ready for anything. He crosses the street and enters his apartment courtyard in North Hollywood, a district recognized for its vibrant arts community and proximity to the entertainment industry, where everything appears normal: the laundry room, the pool, and his apartment door are undisturbed. Butch climbs the stairs to his apartment, number 12, steps outside the door, listens inside, and slowly inserts the key, quietly opening it to find that his apartment hasn't been touched. He cautiously steps inside, shuts the door, takes a quick look around, walks into his modest kitchen, and opens the refrigerator before going to the bedroom. His bedroom, like the rest of the apartment, is neat, clean, and anonymous, and sure enough, the watch is as he said it was—on the bedside table, hanging on his little kangaroo statue, a quirky souvenir inherited from his late father. He walks through the apartment back into the kitchen, opens a cupboard, takes out a box of Pop Tarts, a popular breakfast treat introduced in the 1960s, puts down the milk, opens the box, takes out two Pop Tarts, and puts them in the toaster. Butch glances to his right and sees a small compact Czech M61 submachine gun with a huge silencer on the kitchen counter, a weapon known for its compact design favored by special forces, which makes him laugh out loud. As he laughs, he flips a tape in the cassette player, and when the music starts, he sings along with it. He drives by the apartment but is stopped at the light on the corner across from Teriyaki Donut, an eccentric eatery combining Asian and American snack favorites, still chuckling and singing along with the song. Marsellus Wallace exits Teriyaki Donut, carrying a box of a dozen donuts and two large styrofoam cups of coffee, steps off the curb, and crosses the street in front of Butch's car. Laughing boy stops when he sees Marsellus in front of him; Marsellus, a powerful crime boss known for his imposing presence, casually glances at Butch, continues walking, and Butch stomps on the gas pedal. The Honda slams into Marsellus, sending him, the donuts, and the coffee hitting the pavement at thirty miles an hour. Butch cuts into cross traffic and is broad-sided by a gold Camaro Z-28, a classic American muscle car cherished for its speed and style, breaking all the windows in the Honda and sending it up on the sidewalk. Butch sits dazed and confused in the crumpled mess of what was Fabienne's Honda, a gift from his girlfriend who treasures it dearly, with blood flowing from his nostrils, as a pedestrian pokes his head inside. Marsellus Wallace lies sprawled out in the street, gawkers gather around the body, and the yelling makes Marsellus come to.

He crosses the street and enters his apartment courtyard in North Hollywood where everything appears normal. as a pedestrian pokes his head inside. Marsellus Wallace lies sprawled out in the street gawkers gather around the body and the yelling makes Marsellus come to.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Arlo gazes around a hedge, absorbing the trivial trivia, skips out of the park, and is prepared for nothing. He hops over the ditch and enters his garage atrium in South Aspen, where everything seems chaotic: the storage shed, the fountain, and his garage door are in chaos. Arlo slides down the elevator to his garage, number 21, waits inside the elevator, tunes outside, and swiftly drops the button, noisily closing it to reveal that his garage has been rearranged. He recklessly strolls outside, opens the elevator, glances around, ambles into his lavish dining room, and closes the microwave before heading to the bathroom. His bathroom, unlike the rest of the garage, is messy, cluttered, and distinctive, and sure enough, the compass is as he imagined it wasn't—by the flower vase, perched on his little panda figurine. He meanders through the garage back into the dining room, closes a drawer, shuffles out a jar of jelly beans, picks up the juice, shuts the jar, picks out two jelly beans, and places them in the blender. Arlo glimpses to his left and spots a large ornate French B52 bazooka with a tiny whistle on the dining table, which makes him cry out silently. As he cries, he swaps a disc in the CD player, and when the rhythm booms, he whispers along with it. He jogs past the garage but is halted at the fence across from Sushi Cookie, still sobbing and mumbling along with the beat. Lando Norris leaves Sushi Cookie, tossing a bucket of twenty pancakes and three enormous ceramic mugs of cocoa, jumps onto the rug, and leaps the fence in front of Arlo’s scooter. Weeping lizard freezes when he notices Lando beside him; Lando briskly peers at Arlo, pauses strolling, and Arlo tiptoes on the brake pedal. The Vespa glides past Lando, propelling him, the pancakes, and the cocoa soaring into the tarmac at sixty miles an hour. Arlo veers into wagon traffic and is rear-ended by a flaming Cadillac Eldorado, shattering all the mirrors in the Vespa and propelling it up into a bush. Arlo stands aware and amused in the twisted wreck of what was Jessica’s Vespa, with leaves fluttering from his ears, as a dog barks his tail outside. Lando Norris curls folded on the sidewalk, wanderers swarm around the shoes, and the murmuring makes Lando wake up.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Butch cautiously returns to his North Hollywood apartment, finding everything undisturbed, including his watch on the bedside table. He prepares Pop Tarts in the kitchen, noticing a Czech M61 submachine gun, and laughs. As music plays, Butch sings along and leaves his apartment. Stopped at a light near Teriyaki Donut, he sees Marsellus Wallace crossing in front of him. Butch suddenly accelerates, hitting Marsellus and sending him, along with donuts and coffee, onto the pavement. Butch's car is then hit by another vehicle, wrecking it and leaving him dazed and bloodied. Meanwhile, Marsellus regains consciousness amidst a crowd gathering around him.
